resources.string: Show only named functions in cab
No routes defined, tap to add
Tap to read data from decoder
Prevent screen from blanking when inactive
LokPilot 5 decoders are able to do the automatic decoupling. When you push the function button the loco drives backwards against the train and then removes from it again.
In CV 246 the speed that moves the loco will be stored (or defined) (0–255). If this value is 0, the automatic coupler function is not active.
In CV 247 the time of removing is to be entered (The time the loco needs for moving away from the train).
In CV 248 the time of pushing is to be entered (The time the loco needs for pushing against the train).

The time of removing should be higher than the time of pushing to make sure that the loco stops in a safe distance away from the train. \nThe function output of the option „coupler“ needs to be configurated correctly to make the automatic decoupling work.

The shunting mode reduces the speed (ex factory: to about 50%) for each speed step. Thus, you have smoother control of your locomotive in the lower speed ranges, which is important for shunting, particularly in the 14-speed-step mode. In CV 101 you can set the trim value or shunting mode.
Dimming the light and function outputs
Light functions and function outputs A1 to A7 can be set to any desired level of dimming. These settings are stored in CVs 116 (light), 117 (A1) through 123 (A7).
Secondary dimming of the lighting and function outputs

The lighting and function outputs can be set to alternative dimming settings (for example, a high beam). The settings for the alternative dimming values are stored in CVs 150 to 157 for A0 to A7. This settings can be activated in extended function mapping (CV96 = 1).
Fade-in/fade-out option for lighting and function outputs
When the output is switched on or off, it will fade in or fade out softly.
CV186 is used to specify which output should control this option.
The value of CV187 determines how fast the fade function works.
Blinking effects for lighting and function outputs

The model‘s decoder has a flashing option that can be assigned to the function outputs. Both the activation time and deactivation time of the flasher option can be set separately. CV109 is used to specify which output the flasher option is connected to. Furthermore, the setting of CV110 determines which output will activate the flasher option, when, for example, the model reverses direction.
CV109 is used to specify which output the flasher option is connected to.
Furthermore, the setting of CV110 determines which output will activate the flasher option, when, for example, the model reverses direction.
In CV111 the activation time is adjustable in 100millisecond steps.
In CV112 the deactivation time in 100millisecond steps.
Switch-on effect for a neon light / fluorescent lamp

The switch-on effect of a defective fluorescent lamp can also be assigned to light and function outputs. This effect consists of an adjustable number of flashes (a random flash up to the maximum number of flashes) and an adjustable flash time (i.e. how fast the flashes should follow each another).
The flash time is set via CV 189 in 5 millisecond steps.
The maximum number of flashes is set in CV 190.
Energy-saving lighting effect when switching on light and function outputs
When switching on an energy-saving lamp, it first displays a basic brightness, before it slowly reaches maximum brightness. This effect can be assigned to the decoder outputs as follows.
The basic brightness is adjustable via CV184.
The setting of CV185 determines how fast the final intensity of the brightness (PWM1 in CVs 116 – 123) is reached.
Light outputs A1 to A7 can be assigned random flickering. This effect is typically used for the flickering inside a firebox.
Settings for the flicker rhythm, as well as for the intensity of brightness are entered in CV 182.

Since only one value can be programmed into a CV, the flicker effect results from the sum of the individual values of the flicker rhythm plus the sum of the individual values of the brightness settings (sum of bits 0 – 3 plus sum of bits 4 – 6). The combination of all bits results in a differing, random flicker effect.

A smoke generator can be connected to function outputs A1 to A7, which are controlled by the load–dependent decoder. The physical smoke output from the generator is governed by PWM (Pulse Width Modulation) which is controlled by CV133. When the locomotive moves, the function output receives 100% of the PWM signal. The locomotive motor can be stopped for 0–15 seconds (startup delay) so that the smoke generator heats up when the locomotive is stationary. After the delay, the locomotive starts, and the output is activated to a full 100%. At this point the smoke output is fully controlled by PWM. When the load on the locomotive increases, the PWM adjusts the smoke output again to reflect the heavier load. The required load threshold can be set by the user.
CV130 determines which outputs from A1 to A7 are controlled by the smoke generator control
And when to activate the startup delay
The load threshold is entered into CV131 from a value range of 0 to 127. The larger the value is the slower the output responds to a load change.
CV132 determines the PWM for normal running characteristics
CV133 determines the PWM when the locomotive is idling
Startup (activation) time is entered in CV 134

Electric coupler drives consist of fine copper wire windings that are sensitive to constant current flow, and because of that they heat up rapidly. With the appropriate settings, the decoder will automatically shut off current to a coupler drive without having to shut off the drive via the function key. Also, the decoder uses an adjustable high PWM to ensure that the coupler drive is only activated for a moment to raise the coupler loop. After the loop is raised, only a small amount of current is needed to keep it in the raised position. The lower PWM and required hold time are adjustable. If the coupler does not couple or uncouple properly on the first attempt, the decoder can be programmed to make several more attempts. When adjusting coupling/uncoupling processes, the „as many as necessary; as few as possible“ rule applies. To prevent the coupler windings from burning up from constant current, an automatic shut-off time must be entered in 0.1 second increments, where the coupler drive will pause before carrying out another coupling operation.
CV124 number of coupling operations (0 = no coupler)
CV125 activation time for coupler operation with PWM from CV117 (A1) to CV123 (A7)
CV126 coupler in open position time (holding time for coupler operation)
CV127 deactivation time (pause time for coupler operation) (0 = no functioning)

A switching (shunting) tango can only be carried out if the electric coupler control is activated in CV124 – 129. A switching tango is activated by one of the electric coupler outputs when the decoder speed step is at 0: 
How a switching (shunting) tango works: 
1. The locomotive travels forward for a programmable length and speed (T1) 
2. The locomotive stops and switches its direction of travel 
3. The locomotive uncouples and moves backward at the same speed for the same length (T2) 
4. The locomotive stops and resumes the original direction of travel.
Switching tango with automatic coupling and uncoupling

Changing the function operation with two connected couplings on two outputs: 

1. For the front coupler drive, CV129 is the least significant CV for outputs A1 to A7. So, if A1 and A2 are both used, A1 is for the front coupler and A2 is for the rear coupler. If more (or less) than 2 outputs are used, there is still no difference in the sequence for the different directions of travel (see automatic uncoupling movements). 

2. If the locomotive is traveling forward and the front coupler drive is deactivated via a function key, the coupler drive is also deactivated when the direction of travel is reversed, and the locomotive is running in an automatic switching (shunting) sequence (coupling procedure). If the locomotive is traveling backwards and the rear coupler drive is deactivated, then the front coupler is activated. In either direction of travel, the electric coupler drive is controlled by its respective setting. 

3. The amount of time that the electric coupler drive is activated is adjusted via CVs 124–127 to correspond with the switching (shunting) tango scenario, controlled by CVs 136 and 137. The following rule applies: CV124 multiplied with the sum of CV125 + CV126 + CV127 always must be bigger than the sum of CV136 + CV137. In this case and in other circumstances, additions must be made to the right side of the inequality, because, when the model is running in a switching tango mode, the decoder only reverses the direction of travel when it senses the model is in idle.
CV135 for switching (shunting) gear “switching tango” (speed steps). A CV value of 0 specifies that no switching tango takes place.
CV136 for the pushing movement time T1
CV137 for the reverse movement time T2
Connecting a servo to the decoder requires electronics skill.

CV166 determines which output controls a servo. If the associated value is set, then a control signal for the servo is sent to the desired function output (A6 and/or A7, or SUSI). The following assignment applies to the connection pins of the SUSI interface: Servo1 = CLK, Servo2 = Data.
CV167 function key numbers (F0 - F28) for Servo 1 on SUSI-CLK
CV168 function key numbers (F0 - F28) for Servo 2 on SUSI-Data
The light and function outputs A1 to A7 can be set to any dimming level within a value range of 0 – 64.
The factory setting for each function output is 64.
Flags are options that allow an output to be automatically switched off under certain conditions and to be shown or hidden.

The speed threshold for “Auto-Off Slow” or “Auto-Off Fast” can be set in CV179 “Speed Threshold” in a value range of 0 - 255. \nThe fade-in and fade-out times are set via CVs 177 (fade-in time) and CV 178 (fade-out time) in steps of 20ms in a value range of 0 - 255. \nIf an output has been switched off via an “Auto-Off” condition, Bit5 “Auto-On” can be used to decide whether this output is automatically switched on again when the switch-off condition is no longer met.
Softly fade in and out light and function outputs
When the output is switched on or off, it fades in or out smoothly.
Which output should receive these blend functions is set using the flags in outputs configuration.
Flashing of the light and function outputs
The locomotive decoder has four flashing generators that can be assigned to the outputs
If an output is to use one of these flashing generators, this effect is assigned to the desired output using effect Blinking 1 – 4.
Switch-on effect of a fluorescent lamp, defective fluorescent lamp
The switch-on effect of a fluorescent lamp (multiple flashes before the output is fully switched on) or a defective fluorescent lamp can also be output to the light and function outputs.
The duration of the switch-on effect (start time) can be set in CV 172
The flashing interval of the defective fluorescent lamp is fixed.
Energy-saving lamp effect when switching on the light and function outputs
When an energy-saving lamp is switched on, it initially produces a starting brightness before slowly reaching maximum brightness.
The starting brightness can be set in CV170
The fade-in time to maximum brightness can be set in 100 ms increments in CV171

The use of a servo on the decoder requires electronic expertise due to the servo circuit to be created. \nA maximum of four servo circuits can be operated on the PIKO SmartDecoder XP. The settings for the two stop positions and the speed can be adjusted using three CVs each.
Speed. The higher the value, the higher the speed
Time-controlled switching off of the function outputs
The front light (F0v) and rear light (F0h), as well as A1 - A7, can be automatically switched off after a configurable time has elapsed. The times can be individually set for each output.
Control of a digital coupling (A4 and A5)

Digital couplers can only be connected to decoder outputs A4 and A5. If a shunting tango is also to be used, outputs A4 must be used for the front coupler and A5 for the rear coupler. Which of the two function outputs A4 and A5 should be activated for a digital coupler is set in CV47 using bits 2=1 (A4) and 3=1 (A5). If the front and rear digital couplers are accidentally connected to the wrong outputs—i.e., A4 to the rear and A5 to the front—this can be corrected using bit 4=1 in CV47.

Digital couplers are made of the finest copper wire windings and are used for automatically coupling and uncoupling cars. These are generally sensitive to continuous current flow, as they become relatively hot as a result. With appropriate settings, the decoder can ensure that the function outputs are automatically deactivated after a set time (CV130). \nAutomatically switch off without having to deactivate the function key. Furthermore, the decoder can ensure that the coupler is only controlled with a high PWM for a brief moment of activation to safely raise the coupler. After this moment, less energy is required to keep the coupler raised. This lower PWM can be set in CV 135.
Shunting tango with automatic coupling and uncoupling

A shunting tango can only be activated if the electrical coupling control is activated via CV47. 
A shunting tango is triggered by one of the coupling outputs when the decoder speed step = 0: 

How a shunting tango works during the uncoupling process: If the car is coupled to the rear coupling, for example, the locomotive must be facing forward in the direction of travel. 
1. Locomotive travels at an adjustable speed for an adjustable time T1 against the current direction of travel (press, coupling released) 
2. Locomotive stops and changes direction 
3. Uncoupling process and the locomotive runs at the same speed level for an adjustable time T2 (moving away) 
4. The locomotive stops and now the locomotive has returned to its original direction of travel. 

How a shunting tango works during the coupling process: 
If, for example, the car is to be coupled to the rear coupling, the locomotive must be facing backwards in the direction of travel. 
1. Locomotive travels at an adjustable speed for an adjustable time T1 against the current direction of travel (coupling safely released) 
2. Locomotive stops and changes direction 
3. Lift the bar and the locomotive will run at the same speed for an adjustable time T2 for coupling 
4. The locomotive stops and now the locomotive has returned to its original direction of travel.
CV131 for the speed level of the shunting tango
The value 0 specifies that no shunting tango takes place
CV132 for the pressing time T1
CV133 for the pressing time T2 when coupling
CV134 for the separation time T2 when uncoupling
The total duration of the coupling control may need to be adjusted via CV 130 to the times of the shunting tango in CVs 131 to 134.
Bluetooth permission is required to communicate with command station
Unable to continue without bluetooth permission
Bluetooth adapter is disabled, please enable it

Function mapping chart contains 72 rows and over 1000 CVs. It can take a long time to read it all. \n\nHowever mostly configuration stored in several top rows followed one-by-one. Reading until a blank row can reduce time, but there is a chance something left hidden.

Extended function mapping banks contains 32 lines and over 500 CVs. It can take a long time to read it all. \n\nHowever mostly configuration stored in several top rows followed one-by-one. Reading until a blank row can reduce time, but there is a chance something left hidden.
